text:
My daughters and I made this and it was awesome.  Instead of boiling the water and sugar mixture on the stove I put it in the microwave for 1min. when done I added some ice to cool it down so it did not take long to make at all.  Very refreshing.

text:
This one's a keeper.  Yes, it is labor intensive.  Hey, you might even build up your triceps with all that lemon twisting action - but, if you have the time, the effort is well worth it.  This recipe IS quite sweet, so if your tastes preference runs closer to tart, go easy on the sugar.  I needed six or seven lemons to make  1 1/2 cups of lemon juice.

text:
YUM! This was so good!  And it did not take 4 hours to make, even though I squeezed all the lemons by hand since I didn't have a juicer.  The trick is to soak the lemons in hot water for 10 mins and roll each lemon on the counter before you cut and squeeze.  I only used 1 1/4 C of sugar and added a little more water.  Very good recipe!  Thanks Jo!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I live in Venezuela, where lemons are virtually nonexistent, so I decided to adapt this recipe to make "limeade", with very pleasant results. I used 10 limes to make 1 1/2 cups of juice, added the juice to the syrup mix after it had cooled just slightly, immediately transferred the mixture to a one-gallon pitcher, and topped it off with cold water. The whole procedure took less than ten minutes, and made a very nice alternative to the usual  lemonade.

text:
This was the first time I made lemonade with the simple syrup and I really think it was worth the extra step as it eliminates having to stir forever to make sure the sugar is dissolved. Degree of sweetness is a matter of individual taste and preference, but 1-1/4 cups of sugar was just right for my tastebuds. Will make lemonade with this simple syrup recipe from now on!

None
text:
The family likes this recipe.  The only changes I make is I juice 4 lemons (which gives about 2 cups) and I also juice one orange into it. The orange "rounds out" the flavor.  Also, to get the most possible juice from your lemons?  Nuke each lemon for 30 seconds, turn over and then 30 seconds more.  Makes a big difference in the amount of juice you get and makes it easier to juice them in general.

country:
None
text:
I've made this several times and its always comes out great - The only change I make is to thinly peel the lemons and add the peel to the sugar/water mixture on the stove, cooking for about 10-15 minutes.  It adds extra lemon flavor and adds some lovely color to the lemonade.  Make sure you strain out the cooked peels before mixing in the additional water.

text:
I really like this lemonade. If you think it's too sweet, use as much sugar as you want. I use 1 1/3 -1 1/4 cup of sugar. Depending on the size of your lemons, 1 1/2 cups of lemon juice equals 7-8 lemons. Don't forget to leave the pulp. It makes the lemonade look so pretty and it tastes good, too.

I first made this lemonade at my mom's house for our Mother's Day Dinner and I did not make enough according to my family. I thought everyone would drink most of the soda's and tea that was available so I only made a one gallon jug. My husband loved it so much,  one week later he was chairing a meeting so he wanted me to make the lemonade for him to take and he said everyone just loved it. Since our Mother's Day get together I have received many request from my family to make the lemonade because I do such a great job at it. It is Summer and I have had to make a calendar to keep up with the request of orders from my family on when they want me to fix the lemonade for them. I just need to give them the recipe and let them do it but none have asked so I guess I will keep doing it until I get tried of it.  But being honest with myself I do not get tried of the compliments.  Thanks for sharing.

text:
Wow, melted sugar is the trick... great idea! I made this recipe in 10 minutes. i put water/sugar mix on stove, cut the peel off 5 large lemons and ran them through my electric juicer. I filled a CERAMIC pitcher(dont use glass pitcher) with ice and added lemon juice, then poured the hot syrup in a thin stream through ice. Add water to taste. Yum!

I've never made homemade lemonade before.  Oh my goodness this is the best stuff.  I didn't change a thing from the recipe.  It's not hard at all to make - don't be put off by the 4 hour time-frame....most of that is just to chill the liquids to ice-cold temperatures.  If you are impatient like me, just use ice cubes in your glass!  Thank you, Jo, for a wonderful recipe.  I've shared it with all my friends just now over the internet.  If my husband doesn't come home soon, he's not going to get to taste this stuff....I'm going to drink it all!

This is a refreshing and easy drink. No need for  the fuss of stirring the granulated sugar until it dissolves in the pitcher! I also tried it with limes and it was also good. Sometimes, the lemonade was a little bit too sweet so I added a couple of ice cubes and 1-2 Tbsp more of lemon juice.

Really good and easy to make.  My husband loves lemonade and now this is his favorite recipe!  The ratio of sugar and lemon is perfect for that lip puckering sweet-tart taste.  Tip:  To get the most juice  from your lemons, blast them in the microwave for 10-15 seconds, then roll on the counter.  Juices will burst thru as soon as you begin to cut the lemon open!

text:
This recipe may look like it's too much work just for lemonade, but it really isn't. My syrup boils, cools and is refrigerated for about 2 hours max before I mix it with the juice. 
I find that it takes about 9 large lemons to get enough lemon juice and now I keep a spare batch of simple syrup in the fridge for when I want to make another pitcher.
So very worth it! Just double your simple syrup recipe and put some aside for next time.

country:
None
text:
I live in Beijing, China as an expat teacher, and it's nice to get a familiar taste - many Chinese believe lemonade is this thing called Sprite.  *sigh*

One change I made though is that I cut the sugar down as another user suggested to 1.5C and, to cut down on work and lemons, I quartered and peeled 4 medium lemons, tossed them in the blender with a cup of water; I wound up with two cups of "lemon juice" which were perfect when mixed with the rest of the ingredients.  I also added lemon zest from two of the lemons to the syrup for extra lemon flavour.  Absolutely incredible and refreshing!

text:
This was very sweet. Next time I will decrease the sugar, increase the fresh lemon and add fresh mint. * UPDATE * When we have a million lemons on our tree - we juice the lemons and freeze pre-measured portions for the lemonade in individual freezer Ziplock bags. When you want to make the lemonade, just thaw the frozen bag on the counter for awhile or in the fridge overnight. Nothing tastes as good as fresh squeezed, but this is still better than the store bought frozen (and cheaper).

text:
I make this ALL the time.  Its so easy to do and a huge crowd pleaser.  My family bought me the Cuisanart Pulp Control Citrus Juicer for my birthday! It was only $30 and it is absolutely amazing.  Tip: Make sure you bring your sugar water to a boil so that you see the bottom of the pan.  I used to not let it go all the way out of impatience but when I did, my critics all commented on how it tasted better than usual.  Sometimes if the lemons are small or old you may not get a full 1 1/2 cups of lemon juice.  I've supplemented a 1/4 cup with bottled and it turned out fine.

VERY good!  I do like my lemonade a little more tart, so I cut the sugar to 1-1/4 c and I thought it was perfect. PERFECT pink lemonade!  Flavor was great.

text:
Excellent!!! As with other reviews I cut down sugar to 1 1/2 C. I made simple syrup in microwave until boiling. I only had 3 lemons =2/3 C. of lemon juice. Put lemons in microwave each for 15 sec. then rolled on table to increase ease of juicing. Used Real Lemon juice to make up the 1 1/2 c. of lemon juice. Poured hot syrup over 2 C. ice. Added 5 C. cold water. So I got real pulp and lemon taste w/o squeezing all the lemons. 15 min. tops to make. Also try hot for sore throats, keeps scurvy away!! Happy summer!

userID:

Display Name:
janet7th

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1026129.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is great! After reading the reviews I wanted to make sure I didn't get it too sweet. I frequently find drinks like specialty coffees that are mixed by a barista to company specs too sweet. I made the sugar syrup as directed although you don't have to boil it, just heat it until the sugar dissolves. I made the syrup last night and chilled it overnight. It took 10 medium lemons to yield 1.5 cups of juice. I ended up using about 3/4 of the sugar syrup as  I mixed the juice and water, I added the syrup to taste. Using refrigerated lemons and water along with the refrigerated syrup lets you enjoy the lemonade immediately. This is somewhat labor intensive for the amount it makes - not really enough for a party because it's SOOO good. But I made it as a treat for our 4th of July picnic and it was a nice treat. I'll definitely make it again.

text:
I agree that this is an easy but great tasting recipe.  Just making simple syrup makes all the difference in the texture, and the taste of the Lemonade.  This simple little step, which I never thought of before, made all the difference to such a quick easy recipe. Creating simple syrup prevents small little pieces of unmixed sugar granular from taunting you at the bottom of the pitcher as you mix and mix until you end up with Mixersâ elbow.  The only change I made was to add a splash of fresh lime juice, and one to two  Caffeine Free Stash Peppermint Herbal Tea bags, depending if I doubled the mixture amount or not. I felt this added a nice crisp taste to my Lemonade. Hope others can enjoy this extra step as well.

text:
This was very refreshing, though I found that it was a bit too sweet.  It was perfect when I made it with 1 1/4 cups of sugar.   I used a tip I saw on TV once to make squeezing the lemons easier - after cutting them in half, pop them into the microwave for about 45 seconds.  The juice will run right out of them with minimal effort!  I also boiled fresh ginger slices in my sugar syrup and strained them out afterward.  The gingery kick they added was delicious.

sweetfanatic

city:

text:
I really don't understand why some reviews said that the sugar wasn't enough. It was too much if you ask me. I measured it in my head, and decided to go with 1 cup of sugar for 1 cup of water (for the boiling part). 1 3/4 cups of sugar is too sweet. At first, I thought it would be less for 7 cups of water, but it was perfect! It was actually sweeter than I thought! I drink my lemonade a little bit less sweeter, but the sugar was perfect (reduced from 1 3/4 to 1 cup). I also didn't use lemon juice straight from lemons. First, I didn't have any. Second, it would be more time consuming if I tried to juice 1 1/2 cups worth of lemons! I used organic lemon juice, straight from the bottle, and it tasted just as great! Overall this lemonade was wonderful. Next time, for my own preference, and since I like my lemonade to be "diet", I will add 1/2 cup of sugar. And I'm pretty sure it will still be sweet.
Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
6
userID:
153632
Display Name:
DISCOBUNNY
isPro:
False
followersCount:
30
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
78
favoritesCount:
1204
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/65375.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are basically the same proportions (water, lemon juice, sugar) we've always used to make lemonade since I was a little girl, though I think I may use slightly less juice and closer to 1 cup of sugar (1-3/4 c. sugar seems a lot for a 2 qt recipe).  I have never boiled anything at all.  I just dump the sugar in my pitcher, run enough hot water over it to cover, then stir til dissolved.  That hangs out and cools to room temp while I juice the lemons (about 6 for a 2-qt. pitcher, depending on size).  Then I add the juice to the pitcher and fill to within about an inch of the top with cold water and toss in a few of the squeezed-out lemon halves.  It's delicious right away, but of course it's much more flavorful once it's had a chance to sit the fridge for a few hours.  In my humble opinion, the boiling is unnecessary.  I tried it to see if it made any difference, but I couldn't tell that it did.  To each his own, though -- either way, there's nothing more refreshing and delicious than homemade lemonade on a hot summer's day! :)  Oh, almost forgot to mention -- I am diabetic and normally make my lemonade with Splenda, and you can't tell one bit of difference.  I'm picky about that since sweet iced tea and lemonade are two things I'd rather not have at all than to have with some off flavor.  So don't be afraid to try Splenda!

Display Name:
BABSKITCHEN

text:
After reading a lot of reviews and some people complaining it was too sweet and others complaining it was too tart, I decided to try the recipe exactly as written.  We prefer our lemonade tart and like many others, found it to be way too sweet.  I ended up adding 2 more cups of water and another 1/2 cup of lemon juice (I used bottled since I didn't have any fresh lemons and want to try it with fresh, which I think will be even better) and came up with what we thought was a pretty good batch of lemonade.  Tart like we like it, with just the right amount of sweetness.  I really liked the idea of cooking the sugar and water first.  Although a bit more time consuming, you are assured that the sugar is well blended instead of sitting on the bottom.  Good recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
The best lemonade I have ever tried.  I used a little less sugar than called for and strawberries too.  When I was boiling the sugar water I grabbed 6-7 strawberries and mashed them up before dropping them in the sugar water.  Let it froth up a bit before chilling.  Adds a great strawberry flavor to it and could work with any other berry too.

None
text:
Tastes great!  I found that it is much easier to boil equal parts sugar and equal parts water (1 3/4c each) to make a simple syrup, then add the cooled syrup to the lemon juice and remaining water (6 1/4c).   This cuts down on the time to bring it to a boil and on the cooling time!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE this recipe! It does not take as long as it says and it's not that labor intensive. 

Instead of 1 3/4 cup of sugar, I use 1 1/2 cups. I like mine a little more tart. It takes about 2 minutes for the water to boil with the sugar in it. Once it boils, I pour it into the pitcher with the lemon juice (I own a citrus juicer) and the remaining water. I then add ice cubes (to cool it faster) and a few lemon slices for effect. 

I pop it in the fridge and we're ready to go. Sometimes we can't wait for a glass so if you pour it into a cup with ice, it'll cool down in no time. I just made a batch and I can't wait to enjoy it with dinner later!

text:
This is really good lemonade, but really sweet. I went down to 1.5 cups of sugar and I'll probably use 1.25 next time. I chose this recipe because it calls for lemon juice instead of just lemons. In my experience, not all lemons have the same amount of juice which can throw off the sweet/tart balance. However, I love the simplicity of lemonade and this recipe make a great glass of lemonade :)

text:
Awesome has been used so many times on the review of this recipe but there's no other way to describe it! It doesn't get any easier...then when I cheat and substitute the bottled lemon juice that I had bought in bulk and needed a way to use it up before it went bad. Found this recipe and have make it at least once a week. The kids will either mix it half and half with the iced tea I make (tastes similar to the Arnold Palmer half and half) or like other reviewers have done and used it to blend with some frozen strawberries or blueberries. Whatever we have on hand seems to work! Thanks for sharing Jo!

text:
This was amazing, and the best part is is that it doesn't involve so many lemons to use! I used about 4 large lemons, though I ran out of sugar, but it was fabulous, my husband and I loved it, and almost everyone loved it, but my father-in-law thought it wasn't enough lemons or sugar. But this did not take me four hours, I let my husband roll out the lemons on the table until they became soft making the juices come out much easier. It took him about 5 minutes to squeeze all four. But all in all, this is a keeper, I will be making this again!

text:
Very good recipe for lemonade. Best thing is to keep things basic. I need about 6 medium sized lemons for this. And it is much better to make the simple syrup instead of just adding the sugar. Although, I keep my syrup balanced, equal parts sugar and water (in other words, I cut the sugar back to one cup; It's really all you need).

text:
This is a great standard. I just poured the juice and the simple syrup over a whole lotta ice and topped it off with cold water to equal about three quarts. My husband said, "Well, there's our summer drink."

LATER: Also works with my iced tea maker, where I put the juice and sugar in the pitcher and water up to the 2 quarts line in the machine. When it's done, I stir to dissolve and add ice. Made with Demerara or Turbinado sugar, it's "Mom's Dirty Lemonade" and we love it!

text:
The trick to the perfect lemonade is to keep the sugar water (simple syrup) and the lemon juice seperate until you are ready to drink it. My family has a pitcher of lemon juice and a pitcher of sweetend water at the "bar". We bring our glass of ice and add as much lemon/water as we like. The lemonade is always the perfect flavor for the person drinking it.

text:
Everyone at my party loved it!  I made the "concentrate" ahead of time (the 1 c. water and sugar mixture combined with the lemon juice) and put it in the freezer.  The day before I needed it I took it out of the freezer and put it in the refrig.  The day of the party, all I had to do was mix the concentrate with the remaining 7 c. of water.

country:
None
text:
I love this lemonade and wanted to enjoy it even when there is not a group to drink 8 cups lemonade.....

So I double or triple the amount and make a large batch of sugar-water syrup and store it in glass Quart jars in the refrig.

Then, no matter the number of servings I wish to make, I use equal parts syrup and lemon juice and add 2.3 parts water to it.  Yum

E.g., 1 C syrup + 1 C Lemon Juice + 2&1/3 C Water = 3&1/3 C Delicious Lemonade!

text:
Just helped my 7 year old make this this morning for a family get together.  He put a sign out that said Free Lemonade Samples with small cups.  Everyone liked it so much that he made almost $8.  He never even asked for money, they liked it so well they got out money and were paying him. And it sure made him feel good! ;)
Easy trick, to cool the simple syrup, we put the bowl of syrup in a bigger bowl of ice water.  It was nice an cold in no time at all, like 10-15 minutes!

My 4 yr old Meyer Lemon tree has finally produced a good bunch of lemons here in Florida.  It's December, but my husband still asked for lemonade, so I tried this.  I used Splenda instead of sugar to save the calories and it is wonderful!  The Splenda doesn't have to be heated to melt it either, so there was no need to cool it down before adding the lemon juice and water.  A really simple way to make it...saved time and tastes great!

text:
This is a great recipe. I read a review that said it was labour intensive. A few suggestions : 1) boil the water and dissolve the sugar to make that step easier and 2) pop the lemons into the microwave for 20 seconds before squeezing, it will squeeze out more juice in half the time!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I JUST made this, and it really IS the best lemonade ever! The perfect blend of sweet and tart. I microwaved my sugar & water mixture, to save time. I also pricked my lemons with a fork and gave them a minute in the micro as well, to release all the wonderful juices. I was short on lemons, so I used a few squirts of bottled juice. I went easy on the water, subbing in quite a bit of ice...it was ready to drink much quicker that way. This was a HUGE hit with my family. Forget the HFCS~filled stuff in the can...make your own, and be sure use this recipe!!! Top notch!!!

Great Recipe. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2190197.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this several times. It's perfect just as written, but very forgiving. I was short on lemons, so I squeezed a few limes to make up the difference - delicious! Also, you can cheat a little if you don't want to take the time to make the simple syrup. Just start by putting the sugar in the bottom of the pitcher, then add one cup of very hot water (I nuke it) and stir to dissolve the sugar. If it doesn't completely dissolve, it will when the other 7 cups of water and the juice are added. You can add a little crushed ice into the water to chill it faster, too. A real crowd-pleaser, especially made with fresh lemons!

text:
Absolutely fantastic! Everywhere I go, I'm asked to copy the recipe down for others to have! It's grown to be such a common drink that I have detered from juicing my own lemons and now just pour out the bottled stuff. I refuse to use any other recipe for lemonade! With some experimentations done, the best advice I can give is: Do NOT deviate from the recipe - original is truly the greatest, and dissolving the sugar over the stove is the secret, not the proportions of sugar to water to lemon juice! Cheers!

text:
This was easy and so freakin' delicious! It makes a lot of lemonade too. I used the "Real Lemon" Lemon Juice because I didn't have any lemons. But honestly I'll be making it again the same way. Maybe going as far as buying better, pulpier 100% pure lemon juice. It's just so easy! When I tasted it I found it a bit too sweet. I simply added more ice and it tasted perfect. I like a icy-cold lemonade so making it extra sweet is best anyhow so you don't have a bland water-down drink.

text:
I just taught Vacation Bible School and we taught 85 children how to make this lemonade to raise money for Alex's Lemonade Stand (Children Cancer Research).  I made the syrup in advance, 1 1/4 cup of sugar to 1 cup of water.  The children had a blast squeezing the lemons with an old fashioned Rival lemon squeezer.  They added their squeezed juice to the pitcher of 7 cups of water and 1 1/4 of syrup.  We raised over $225.00 at .50 a glass.  Thank you for a fabulous recipe that adults and children, alike, will drink!

I love this lemonade recipe.  I do cut the sugar down to 1 cup, however, because it's a bit sweet otherwise.  I have also substituted limes, as well as using club soda to make sparkling lemonade or limeade.  It's been a hit all summer.

text:
The name says it all.  We are addicted to it and can't get enough and family and friends love it too.  I also throw in a large pinch of salt to stop any bitterness.  I like it best made from 2 fresh lemons and the balance in bottled 'Real Lemon' juice.  If I just use all lemons, the 'bite' of tart and sweet just isn't there.  Using the 2 real lemons also allows for some pulp. Making the 'simple syrup' and letting it chill before mixing makes a big difference in the taste.  Thank you for sharing this recipe.

I made this much quicker than the recipe says. I bought a 2# bag of lemons, which turned out to be perfect. I soaked them in hot water then rolled them on the counter before juicing them. Took about 30 minutes, super cheap, and worth every ounce of effort.

text:
I made this with my preschool class.  Here's what we did: each child rolled a lemon to get the juices flowing.  Then we cut them in half and took turns squeezing the lemons (12 lemons made the perfect amount for us).  We strained the juice to make sure no seeds or pulp got in.  Instead of boiling, we simply mixed the ingredients together.  Best lemonade I've ever had and so simple (if you've got 12 kids doing the hard part of squeezing 12 lemons lol)

text:
Best recipe ever!  We make this continuously and actually find that 1-1/2 cups of sugar is plenty.     For raspberry lemonade, follow step one using only 1 cup sugar.  Mash 2 cups raspberries (fresh or frozen) with the remaining sugar.  Strain and add to step 2.  Delicious!

The best is right!  Just made it for my family and it's awesome.  For a twist I changed it up a bit.  Instead of a whole cup of water during the simple syrup process I used 1/2 cup of water and 1/2 cup pureed fresh strawberries.  Boiled it as directed and then put it through a strainer to catch the seeds and mush.  It came out wonderful.  Next time I will make the recipe exactly as directed but this time we were trying to get rid of 15 lbs. of strawberries that we picked from a local farm.

My father never likes the lemonade that I make. He always says something negative about it. When I made this lemonade I really liked it and so did my brothers and my mom. I had found out that my dad loved it too when he took one big cup and a small cup of it in to his room. I was very happy about it and I made some more today. It is a great recipe and I think that all will enjoy it. For me it was a bit too sweet so, I put a bit less sugar in it and it was a lot better. I had put only 6 cups of water in and that amount was just perfect. Right away I poured the hot syrup into the pitcher but, I had to add a lot of ice to it on a hot day like today. I hope you enjoy!! ;)

country:
None
text:
Was never a big fan of Lemonade until I found this recipe. Now it's a staple in the 'fridge. The first time I made it, it was a bit to sweet for my taste, so the second cut back on the sugar a bit, you can always add more you want it sweeter. Only change I make is once the sugar has dissolved and cooled just a little, I pour it over 2 cups of ice (as Alton Brown always says "a pints a pound the world around")then mix the rest together and float a few lemon slices. Let chill a bit and enjoy.

text:
I'm not a huge lemonade drinker, but I enjoyed this treat. It was, however, pretty labor intensive for the relatively small amount of lemonade it produced, but that is to be expected with fresh-squeezed juice. The rest of my family loves lemonade, and they drank this right up! I recommend keeping the pulp if you can; it really adds to it. I substituted Splenda for about half of the amount of sugar the recipe called for, but next time I would just deal with the extra calories and use sugar.

text:
Mmmmm.... perfect! I've never made lemonade before and the whole family loved this! I made the sugar mix with 1/2 cup sugar and 1/2 cup Splenda with 1 cup water. Plenty sweet. could even cut the sugar back a bit more and it would be fine. Definitely worth the extra time and effort. I followed another reviewers advice and let the lemons sit in hot water for 10 minutes, rolled them on the counter, then squeezed them. Even the kids helped. Thank you!

text:
Very good!  I halved the recipe and microwaved the sugar in 2 cups of water until dissolved.  I used "Italian Volcano Lemon Juice" (not from concentrate).  I thought it was a tad on the sweet side but it might've been the lemon juice.  Next time I won't make a simple syrup...I'll just add sugar to the water and lemon juice.  In the same amount of time it would take the simple syrup to cool, the sugar will have dissolved and will taste the same.  This is how I've always made lemonade.

text:
I have never made fresh lemonade so I searched and searched for a good recipe and this is it!  I had to squeeze the lemons by hand since I don't have a juicer so I popped them in the microwave for about 30 seconds until they felt lukewarm.  This made squeezing a sinch and I was able to get more juice out of each lemon.  I thought it was a little sweet so I may reduce the sugar the next time I make it, but that is a personal preference.  Thanks for sharing!!

We have two lemon trees in our back yard and this was perfect for a summer drink.  Its so versatile too - I followed the exact recipe and was very pleased with the outcome. 
You could easily add more lemon juice and water if you wished to water it down or create a more tart version - but I enjoyed both the sweet and then tart taste that this produced!

text:
This recipe didn't take 4 hours.  I heated the sugar and 1 C.water until it was melted all the way, then shut it off.  Then I slowly poured it into the 7 C.Water and lemon juice mixture.  It was a little lukewarm after that, so I just poured it over ice cubes.  Delish!!!  Oh, use an electric juicer! It takes just a few minutes!

text:
This is exactly how we make lemonade. Simple syrup is wonderful for many things...we like to make a batch for ice tea and leave it in the refrigerator. That way everyone can make their tea as sweet as they like w/out undissolved sugar crystals at the bottom of the tea. We also like to mix this lemonade mix with unsweetened tea instead of the water...lemonade tea.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really great lemonade-- not too sweet nor too tart.  If you don't have time to wait till the sugar syrup cools, instead of the 8 cups of water, fill your pitcher completely with ice.  Put about two cups of cold water into your sugar syrup and pour the sugar syrup onto the ice.  It will melt some ice.  Then, add enough water to fill the rest of the pitcher.  When the ice melts, it will dilute the lemonade a little, but not too much since it's not really adding much water past the initial recipe.  The first few sips with frozen ice still in it might be a little more tart, but not at all sour.  

We used this at our lemonade stand and people LOVED it; we sold three big pitchers in a few hours.   Get one of those flip-top lemon squeezer gadgets and the hassle of squeezing all those lemons changes to fun.  Couldn't keep the kids from doing it!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe. I added a cup and a half of lemons, 3/4 cup sugar, and 7 cups cold water. The lemonade was sweet enough and refreshing. I added 1 cup  boiling water, either from a hot pot or microwaved, to the sugar and let it dissolve in a glass bowl. I cut the lemons into quarters and microwaved them for 3-4 minutes. It was much easier to squeeze the juice out after they were microwaved. I do allow the lemons to cool a bit after microwaving, so I don't burn my hands. I squeeze the juice over a sieve into the sugar water mixture; then pour it into 7 cups cold water and serve immediately over ice or refrigerate till chilled.

text:
I used this recipe to make homemade lemonade for the first time this summer and now my family won't drink store bought lemonade! I actually use a little extra sugar, about 2 cups, and add most of the sugar/water mixture to the lemonade, then taste it and decide whether or not to add the rest. I think some lemons must be more tart then others because some batches need more sugar than others. A tip if you are squeezing the lemons by hand: let the lemons come to room temperature and roll them on the counter to soften them up before squeezing.

text:
Delicious!  For a healthy twist, substitute Pure Vermont Maple Syrup for the white sugar.  Pure Maple is a low glycemic index food, packed with anti-oxidants and minerals (a serving of pure maple syrup has more potassium than a banana), and tastes great.  In fact, because of the "sweet" taste, you can use less than you would traditional sugar, cutting calories.

Buy it at your local grocery store or online.

text:
I just recently dug out my Black & Decker Electric Citrus Juicer, so I'm making every lemon and limeade recipe I can find... I made this, subbing 1/2 C Splenda and 1 C Erythritol for the sugar (hate hate hate the taste and after-taste of anything with straight Splenda).  Fan-freakin'-tabulous!!! And with the electric juicer it only took 6 lemons and about 6 minutes for all that juice.

text:
Great base recipe. I just needed to know the ratio of lemon juice to sugar to water (1:1:6 worked for me). Here's how i make my single serving in minutes! Put 1 tbsp honey and 6 tbsp water in glass. Microwave 30 seconds. Stir to dissolve honey. Add 1 tbsp fresh lemon juice. Add some ice. Done! I like making it fresh daily and drinking immediately because if left out long, vitamin C breaks down.

Good base recipe, but I would cut back on the sugar. I bought a bag of lemons and used them all for 1.5 cups of lemon juice and I found this to be too sweet. Didn't have any more fresh lemons, so I grabbed the bottle of lemon juice from my fridge and added another 1/2 cup. Yes!

text:
My 6 year old daughter and I just made this today and her review is: I think this is terrific! We used 1 1/4 cups of sugar, which was plenty sweet for us. We did make the sugar syrup and just let it cool on the stove while we juiced 6 large lemons (soaking them in hot water for a few minutes and rolling them on the counter before juicing really helps). Then we added the sugar syrup to the strained lemon juice and added 8 cups of water. This is the perfect drink on a hot summer day and so easy to make, especially with a child.

country:
None
text:
The first thing I did was dissolve 1 1/4 cups of sugar in 1 1/2 cups of HOT tap water and let that cool.  I refrigerated it overnight because I was too tired to squeeze lemons.  The next day I had a lightly sweet simple syrup!  I hand squeezed 8 whole lemons to get exactly one cup of lemon juice. (That was a lot of work!)  With 1 cup of lemon juice in the pitcher, I added 5 cups of cold water and 1 cup of my simple syrup.  Thankfully that was perfect.

text:
Yummy!  Tastes like summertime in the shade with a cool breeze.  We tried with limes, too, and it worked great.  I also set some of the lime juice aside to do a sugar-free version with stevia powder, which I thought was even better.  Lighter flavor, WAY fewer calories.  Try about 1 - 1 1/2 Tablespoons stevia powder to 2 quarts limeade.

userID:
2908393
Display Name:
DelightfulDines
isPro:

79

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/146843.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This lemonade was VERY good. I made a few changes but my changes did not change the overall taste of this recipe. I cut back on the sugar by 1/4 cup to total 1 1/2 cups. I also did not wait for the mixture to get to room temperature. I took it right off the stove and put in several large blocks of ice and put it in the refrigerator for 10 minutes until cooled. I only added 6 cups of water because I added ice to cool the mixture and I didnt want it to become too watery. I served it chilled over ice and added my own strawberry puree. I took about 2 cups of frozen whole unsweetened strawberries and put them in a food processor while still frozen. I processed them until they were chopped and then added them to a blender with about 1/2 cup of water and 3 tbsp. sugar. I blended it until smooth and added about 2 tbsp. puree per glass of lemonade and topped it with whipped cream. My only complaint is that it doesnt make enough for an average family of 4 who loves lemonade, it was gone ine 1 day :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect Lemonade! I discovered that my ice cube tray takes two cups of water to refill. So after boiling the water and sugar mixture together, I let the syrup cool for about five minutes before dumping an entire tray of ice cubes (equal to two cups of water) in the syrup. Then I add the remaining five cups of water and lemon juice, stir until all the ice is melted, and it's ready to drink. This speeds up the process considerably!

text:
WOW!  A friend of mine brought over a huge bag of lemons from her tree and the first thing I thought to make for the hot weather we have been having is fresh lemonade.  This is an amazing, simple recipe!  Seems too simple to be so good, but so not so!  I used all fresh lemons and though the lemons were very juicy, much juicier than those I usually buy at the store, I needed ALOT of lemons, but so worth it if you can!  I made the simple syrup a few days ago and put it in the fridge until I had a chance to start squeezing the lemons.  Turned out great!  A keeper recipe for sure!  Thanks!

My DIL was making her famous fried chicken. Famous because she makes them about once a year! I made the simple syrup at home and chilled it. Asked her to get 8 lemons on her way home. DH and I squeezed the lemons together while DIL cooked and Son made smashed garlic potatoes. Added the 7 C. water, then syrup to the correct sweetness. Had some left over, but GREAT lemonade.  Can't wait to make it again, since it got left at DIL's house.

Excellent recipe!!!  I first washed and dryed the lemons, then bake them for an hour at 325 degree on a cookie sheet lined with a cooling rack turning once. I let them cool to room temp. text:
Jo, I just finished making your lemonade.  If I could rate it 10 stars I would! From start to finish I was done in 10 minutes (using an electric juicer to accomplish that).  Another viewer stated that she cut the sugar to one cup.  Knowing you can add & not take away, I started with 1 cup simple syrup in fear it would be too sweet.  Well, as the saying goes "Don't mess with perfection", I added the rest of the 3/4 cup simple syrup and VOILA!  The perfect blend of sweet and tart.  This truly is the "Best Lemonade Ever".  It took me back 45 years to my front yard with my 1 cent lemonade stand!  Thank you for the memories and taking the time to post your recipe.

text:
Really, MSI, haven't you ever heard of simple syrup? Simple syrup is the way cooks incorporate sugar into cold drinks like lemonade, iced tea, mojitos, etc. If you added plain sugar and "mixed it all together," you'd end up with a sugar sludge on the bottom of the glass or pitcher. This is really basic stuff.

country:
None
text:
I noticed that this recipe calls for more sugar than actual lemon juice.  Also, a few other reviews thought this recipe made lemonade that was too sweet.  I like my lemonade quite lemon-y and tart (but not pucker-face tart), so I reduced the sugar to 1 and a quarter cups and to my amazement it was still too sweet for me!  I added in an extra 1/2 cup of freshly squeezed lemon juice to tone it down further.  Something to consider if you prefer your lemonade more on the tart side.  Also, 6 average sized lemons for me made 1.5 cups of lemon juice using a simple citrus juicer.

text:
This really is the best ever! My one and only lemonade recipe now, because it tastes so much fresher than canned, powdered or frozen varieties.  I use stevia instead of sugar since I am diabetic.  I heat about 1 cup of the water to warmish and dissolve the stevia in it.  (I only use about 1 and 1/3 c stevia).  Then I just add this to the other ingredients.  I had some unsweetened cherry juice left over from something else and added 1-2 T -- fantastic.

text:
I love this recipe because it's so easy to make, and I always have Minute Maid lemon juice on-hand in my freezer. I prefer my lemonade with pulp, but I never buy lemons. One thing I do differently with this recipe is to boil the water and then dissolve the sugar; sometimes I add herbal or green tea (peppermint is great) to the water, but my husband says that at that point it's actually iced tea and not lemonade.  Thanks for the recipe, Jo!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
** Thirst quenching happiness in a glass **
I took the time to read the most helpful reviews and went to work.  I soaked my lemons in hot water for 10 mins.  While my lemons were soaking I boiled 1 and 1/4 cup of water with 1 and 1/4 cup of sugar.  While the sugar/water (simple syrup) was cooling I rolled my lemons and hand squeezed them over a stainless steel mesh colander right into the pitcher.  I poured the simple syrup and water into the pitcher, rest of the water and mixed well.  So good, so refreshing and really didn't take that long at all.  I will definitely make this again!

This is a perfect base recipe.   Make it as written and you won't have a drop leftover.  
After some experimenting, we found that we most love it with 1.5 c sugar and we start with 7 cups of water and add more to taste.  But that has to do with the flavor and ripeness of the lemons available that day, not the recipe.  We actually bought an electric citrus juicer because of this recipe.

text:
Too much sugar, the lemonade was WAY too sweet, yuck! also, too little water. - I did, however, make some alterations to the recipe: I took away some of the sugar, instead of 1 Â¾ cups of sugar, I did 1 1/3 cups of sugar. I also added some water, instead of 8 cups, I did 9 cups. That made it better. I also changed the way I did the sugar, instead of bringing the sugar to a boil and then leaving it out to cool, I stood next to the sugar and stirred it every 10 seconds or so until it had dissolved, then I took it off the heat and let it cool down for about 15 minutes and then put it in a Â½ quart salsa jar and set it in the freezer for about 20 minutes. Next, I juiced the lemons and took out SOME of the pulp. And finally I combined the lemon juice and sugar syrup and put it in a pitcher and added the 9 cups of water plus one tray's worth of ice cubes and stirred it up.

text:
Great recipe . Just wanted to share if you only want a large glass and only have a few lemons here is the ingredients  by a third.

1/3 and 1/4 cups white sugar

2 2/3 cups water (just fill a glass with this much water and pull 1/3 and 1/4 cup out of it for the simple sugar)

1/2 cups lemon juice

Nice large lemon you should get about a half a cup.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6524823.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I modified this a bit because I'm lazy:

Pour two cups of sugar into a gallon jug (I used an empty Hawaiian Punch jug).

Fill the jug about halfway with hot water from the tap, screw on the cap, and shake violently for about a minute.

Uncap, add 2 cups of lemon juice (I used ReaLemon, again because I'm lazy and also I had no lemons) and ice or cold water to fill, then recap and shake again for a bit.

Even using bottled lemon juice, it was surprisingly good. Definitely something to consider next time I'm thirsty, there's nothing in the house, and I'm too lazy/broke to go into town and get something.

text:
If you like sweet lemonade, this is it!  It depends on what kinds of lemons you use (Meyer vs. regular lemons), but I would mix the lemon juice + water first, then add half the simple syrup and increase from there.  You'll probably need less syrup, too, if you add fresh fruit to the pitcher as well.  I macerated some strawberries the night before and added about a cup of them to the recipe, so due to all the sweetness in that mix-in, I could use less simple syrup.

country:
None
text:
Great recipe. 
Tricks: 
You don't need to boil. Sugar dissolves just fine in water. Just mix and wait for it to clarify ( it will dissolve faster in warm tap water.) I make simple syrup daily (which is just sugar and water.) some people swear by the boil but I can't taste the difference.

You can buy lemon juice (not the stuff in the green bottle but like normal juice in quarts) It is 95% as good as fresh. I get mine at a restaurant food supply, but you can find it in normal groceries.

Enjoy!

text:
I am rating the recipe as is. To make it to my liking, I had to reduce the sugar to 3/4 cup. I still used 7 cups of water and 1.5 cups of lemon use. I followed the others suggestions and placed about six large lemons in a bowl of very warm water for 10 minutes before rolling them on the counter and juicing them. It was much easier to juice this way. I love the simple syrup though. It melds the flavors so much better!

My grand kids were visiting and we were swimming on a hot southern CA afternoon.  I defrosted lemon juice that I squeezed and froze months ago, mixed the sugar with hot water from the tap, stirred until sugar dissolved, which just took a few swirls, then added the lemon juice...stirred again before adding ice.  Delicious, but sweet.  The kids loved it...I think, I will mix mine with some sparkling water.  A keeper!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have an "Orange X" citrus squeezer from Williams-Sonoma that makes quick work of juicing the lemons.  Since I live in FL, I have lemon trees in my yard, so I used my own fresh-picked, organic Meyers lemons for this recipe.  Two lemons gives me 1.5 cups of juice.  I use 3/4 cups Truvia instead of sugar and use a combo of crushed ice from my fridge with filtered water.  I skipped the part about boiling and making the simple syrup. Best lemonade!  For a special, special treat, add a splash of Absolut Limon.

None
country:
None
text:
This is terrific lemonade !!  So much better then frozen cans or bottled. I used 5 lemons and was just shy of the 1 1/2 cups juice needed so I added lemon juice concentrate to make up the rest.  I put my whole lemons into water and let it come to a boil then moved the pan off the heat and let them soak for about 1/2 hour (less time would work). I squeezed the lemons by hand and pulled out all seeds with a ice tea spoon - that was the most time consuming thing. ENJOY!

country:

text:
Perfect as is! It does make a lemonade on the sweeter side, but it was by no means too sweet!  I did dissolve the sugar with an equal amount of water in the microwave (1-2 minutes depending on how much sugar you're trying to dissolve) before adding it to the rest of the water/lemon juice. That way it didn't have to sit in the fridge for several hours before we could enjoy!!!  My family has requested that this become a regular fixture in our house and I agree!

text:
Heads up: how good this recipe is does strongly depend on your personal taste. I followed it exactly and found it to be a little tart, but I like tart, so I wouldn't change it. My boyfriend on the other hand likes his sweeter, so he would tone it down. Bottom line: if you like it just a little tart, keep it the way it is. If you don't, increase the sugar or cut back the lemons.

text:
Even in the middle of December - I get requests to make this at every gathering. Sometimes I do classic lemonade and sometimes I blend up a variety of fruit (strawberries, blueberries, raspberries, or mango) with the lemon juice. If I add fruit to the lemon juice in a blender, I lessen the sugar in the simple syrup because the fruit has sugar in it.

This really is the best lemonade ever! It taste just like the famous hot dog on a stick kind. My husband & I enjoyed making it together and it was perfect as a summer treat...sent the recipe to family & friends too. I added a little ice to the syrup once room temp to speed the process along. I also put the lemon juice, water, and syrup in the freezer to chill. We went from lemons to sipping lemonade in about 45 mins this way.

userID:
1414774
Display Name:
AUSSIEMUM1
isPro:

45

madeRecipesCount:
223
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/23546.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is very nice. I have made lemonade with sugar syrup before and I've found that tasting as you go along is the only measure to get it exactly right for your personal preference, because sometimes lemons are more tart. Because of some of the other reviewers saying it was too sweet, I cut the sugar to 1 1/2 cups. I did use the microwave to heat the sugar syrup and added a tray of ice cubes to cool it down quick (in about 3 minutes). I poured the syrup and lemon juice in a jug and poured it into an empty, cleaned 3 Litre juice bottle that we just finished. I then added 8 cups of cold water from the fridge. Again, I shook the bottle at 7 cups of water, tasted, bit too sweet and tartish, so I added another cup of cold water. Perfect. If it is too sweet and you've run out of lemons, try adding more cold water and serve over ice cubes. The tip about letting the lemons sit in warm water for a few minutes really does help with juicing them.

For those of you like me who don't use white sugar, I used 3/4 cup raw sugar and 1/2 cup agave syrup (which is much more sweet than sugar) to the recipe, which made it plenty sweet - so sweet I had to add in about one extra cup of lemon juice!  Unfortunately the brown sweeteners made it mustard-colored lemonade!  Very good though!

text:
Excellent.  I made for a brunch..I substitued some of the water for seltzer water (not club soda-it has a different taste)-substitute how much water for the seltzer whether you use by the can (about 2 cans) or by the bottle (1).  It gives it a little fizz.  Put in some strawberries if desired.  If you dont use the whole thing thats ok the seltzer changes into the water.   Great for potlucks or brunch.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect recipe! I cut it in half because my pitcher wasn't big enough for all that liquid. I did use a tiny bit less sugar and 5 lemons to get enough juice for half the recipe. It's so worth the work to squeeze those lemons..if you don't have a plastic citrus juicer that catches the seeds and extra pulp you must get one before trying this recipe. Soaked the lemons in hot water and rolled them on the counter before juicing. It didn't take 4 hours to make this recipe..I just poured in cold water and a handful of ice cubes and I was good to go. Also used several fresh mint leaves, bruised them to bring out the minty flavor before adding to individual glasses of lemonade. Cool and refreshing on a hot Florida summer day!

text:
Delicious.  Everything lemonade should be.  Followed some others suggestions and soaked the lemons in hot water for 10 minutes before squeezing and this softened them up a lot--made squeezing much easier.  1 3/4 cups of sugar is the perfect amount, not overly sweet at all.  You could get away with a little less, but why would you want to?  This is a treat!

text:
It truly is the best lemonade!  You can also use this to make orangeade as well!!!  Just make the sugar water as stated in the recipe (although, I don't bring it to a boil, sugar dissolves in cold water too) and I add fresh squeezed orange juice (OJ from a carton doesn't taste the same) to each individual glass.  1/2 orange for 1 cup of sugar water then I add a couple of maraschino cherries and  some of its juice for color.  AMAZING!!

text:
Instead of boiling the lemons, you can also put them in the microwave for 30-40 seconds to release more juice.  They should be stored at room temp rather than in the fridge, too.  

A citrus press is awesome for juicing lemons, limes and small oranges ~~ much like a garlic press but larger and gets every bit of juice out of the lemon!

text:
We recently bought a house that has a lemon tree.  My boys picked some and have been begging for lemonade.  I used 1 1/2 cups sugar,  1 3/4 cup juice, and about 7 1/2 cups water.  I strained the juice because my kids won't drink pulp.  I did not boil the sugar, I used superfine sugar and it melted quickly.  It made this recipe very easy and quick.

It was a hit with my kids and I really liked it too!

5

text:
This really is the best lemonade I have ever had!  Most homemade ends up tasting too sweet or too sour to me.....this is just perfect.  Not too watery either.  I didn't add quite as much sugar as listed but pretty close.  I put in the lemon juice, water, and 1 1/3 cups sugar and just adjusted to taste from there.  Also, I didn't heat it and do the syrup....just mixed cold and it turned out great.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This took me a dozen small lemons to get 1.5 cups of juice. I hope that piece of info can help others judge how many lemons to buy. I only used 1 & 1/3 C. Sugar as well. Once I tasted it, I decided to add more water as it tasted a bit thick to me with just 8 cups of water. I can only imagine how syrupy it would have been adding all the sugar it suggested. All in all: 1.5 cups of lemon juice, 1 & 1/3 C. sugar, and about 10 - 11 cups of water. I highly suggest adding your sweetener slowly and tasting as you go.
Review:
Rating:
5

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I haven't made lemonade in years.  Well, it's 102 degrees today, and since it is too HOT for outside, and I had a bag of lemons, why not make lemonade!  There is no question it is worth taking the extra step to make the simple syrup.  I cut the sugar to 1 1/2, used 8 lemons (small to medium in size) and approx. 8 cups of water.  I added some ice to the syrup to cool it, which probably made more than 8 cups of water.  I used my old fashioned Juice-O-Matic to juice the lemons.  I gave it 4 stars because it was still too sweet with 1 1/2 cups sugar.  Next time I intend to try it with 1 cup of sugar.  Very refreshing (especially with a little vodka and a mint sprig!)!

Excellent!  This will be my go-to lemonade recipe.  This was my first time making lemonade with simple syrup, as I usually make it with Truvia (Stevia sweetener) but wanted to make something special for my hubby on this hot summer day.  I followed the recipe to a T other than adding ice cubes to quickly cool down the simple syrup.  It took 6 lemons to yield exactly 1-1/2 cups of lemon juice.  In addition to the ice I had added to cool down the syrup, I added the full 8 cups of water and also some more ice in each glass.  My hubby likes things extra sweet, so I added a few packets of Truvia to the full pitcher, but it's great as is and this is a 5-star recipe as is.
Review:

text:
I took a few shortcuts, but the lemonade was still delicious. I took 3 cups of ice, put it in the pitcher, then added 3 cups of water and lemon juice concentrate. After making the syrup, I allowed it to come to ~100F then added it to the mixture.  I will probably reduce the sugar by a 1/4 cup next time.

text:
My rule of thumb is to try a recipe exactly as written once. Then if I choose to make it again, make adjustments to it. This was made with fresh lemons of off a tree in Arizona. BEST lemonade I ever had! When I make it again, I might add some lime,  strawberries, or cherries if I have some available. I did follow some suggestions from other reviews.... heating the lemons in the microwave for 30 seconds, rolling lemons on counter ( I usually do), and heating the sugar/water in the microwave. Thank you for posting those suggestions!
***Great Recipe***

text:
I loved the idea of making simple syrup instead of trying to dissolve the sugar in the cold mixture. Like others have said, the amount of sugar called for in the recipe is too much. I followed the recipe (added a few extra lemons because that's the way I like it) but was able to make two batches with the amount of simple syrup I had.  Which I was thankful for because the first pitcher was gone within what seemed like minutes! We are pretty much obsessed with homemade lemonade in this house now!

text:
This lemonade really is perfect. It was a little on the sweet side but we liked it. I believe next time I will add some strawberries. My kids like me to keep lemonade and sweet tea on hand so they can make Arnold Palmers so this made them very happy. UPDATE: I was in a pinch one day and only had 2 lemons and 2 limes and a bottle of Minute Maid concentrated lemon juice. I used the juice of 1 lemon and 1 lime mixed with the concentrated lemon juice instead of all fresh and it came out excellent! I used the extra lemon and lime sliced to throw in the pitcher just to make it pretty. I will definitely be using this quick option again!

text:
I didnât have fresh lemons so I used the liquid lemon juice bottles I get from Costco. Worked great. The bottles come in 2 packs and I can make appx 6 gallons of lemonade!!! Well worth the price and mixed great with homemade unsweetened black tea. The other thing I did was I make batches of simple syrup in mason jars and keep them in my fridge (for tea) so I just boiled water and added equal parts water and sugar to a mason jar and shook it maybe 10 times till it was dissolved then tossed it in the fridge to cool. Itâs nice to have it in liquid form in the fridge since I hate granulated sugar chunks in my tea. This recipe makes it so I can have a cheap bulk drink for my kids.

text:
I used 1 1/2 cups sugar stirred in 1 cup water and microwaved 2 minutes. I let the syrup cool and added the 1 1/2 cup lemon juice and stored in a glass jar. I love to use this as concentrate- about 50-50 ratio with water, or adding to plain iced tea.
I gave it a four because I also felt the recipe was much too sweet. The next time I will use 1 1/4 cups sugar, which is a half cup less than the recipe.

text:
This recipe is heavenly! I enjoyed making it, but  if you want to make this in 20 minutes not 4 hours, make the syrup, and chill in the freezer for 5 minutes. Then fill a pitcher with ice cubes, and add water & lemon juice, and syrup to the pitcher. Mix together.  I did this and it was incredibly sour.  I love sweet lemonade, so I added another 3/4 of sugar, but if you are the sour  lemonade type, keep as is.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been wanting to experiment with a Lemonade recipe to try and find what my Grandmother used to make when I was a kid (60 years ago).  This comes pretty close.  When I make this again, I will cut back the sugar to 1.5 cups instead of the 1.75.  It was just a bit sweet.  It took me 6 medium size lemons to yield the 1.5 cups of juice.  I use the attachment on my KitchenAid mixer, so that part is a easier.  The lemons were 57 cents each at the store, so a pitcher of lemonade was 3.42.  I will watch when I can get a better deal on lemons.  Then do the squeeze and cook the syrup and freeze them.  Doing the hard(er) steps when I have time will make a pitcher of great lemonade when I want it or when somebody stops by a snap.

Love it! Such a simple, healthy recipe! Yes, even with sugar, it beats all the fake "powdery" lemonade mixes in cans, which are loaded with dyes and additives or the ones labeled as lemonade in the juice or soda section. It took less than 8 lemons and I bought a few extra to slice as a garnish. The whole family loved it and this will definitely be a great drink coming up this summer. Note: It is a bit on the sweet side but I really don't mind this, I can add a bit of water to it or just cut back on the sugar. I prefer using the recipe, as is, and adding water to the cup if someone wants it more diluted. ????

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Very good. It is definitely sweet, but I like it. If you don't like it too sweet, add half the simple syrup, taste it and add more until it's just right. If you wind up with leftover syrup, save it for cocktails or even coffee. If you've already made it, add more lemon juice to cut back on the sweetness. 


                     I made it twice. The first time, I followed it exactly. The second time, I mixed the water and lemon juice, stirred it a little, added the piping hot simple syrup and stirred well. The lemonade was warm, but it cooled in the fridge. It tasted the same and was s little easier and took less time overall.

text:
I prefer my lemonade more tart -- I found this recipe to be very sweet. I found it helpful to go light on the sugar, I used a 1/4 cup less than called for. I also added extra lemon juice, approximately an additional 1/3 cup.  I added the zest of one lemon to the sugar water when boiling as well, and strained it out when adding the sugar water to the water and lemon juice to add a bit more lemon flavor.

text:
My 14-year-old grand nephew made this with lemons grown in the backyard. I was very impressed by his resourcefulness! He followed the instructions, but a bit LARGE quantity. He split into halves and mixed each half in the blender.

His review:
"Pretty good. It has a nice mix of sweet and sour. it's not at all bland." Was he proud of his accomplishment? "Yes I am."

His 11-year-old triplets siblings had the following to say:

Brother #1: "The flavor just explodes your mouth! For people who LOVE sour? Probably not the best, but I like it!."

Brother #2: "I like the pulpy of the lemon and the sweetness of the sugar -- it combines to make it taste really good." 

Sister: "A little too sweet for my liking. I like it a little more sour."

Housekeeper says: "Deliciousa!"

Auntie says: "Truly a PERFECT lemonade! Perhaps stir it up each time you serve so the pulp is in glass..."

Congrats, Chef!!!

text:
Delicious and refreshing!  We don't have a juicer, so we juiced the lemons by hand.  First we soaked the lemons in hot water for 10 minutes.  Then we rolled them on the counter until they were soft.  After cutting them in half, we placed the halves, one by one, in a Ziploc bag and used a rolling pin to squeeze every last drop out.

text:
This was my first try at making homemade lemonade since I was a kid and this came out great! It took me about 8 lemons to make the lemon juice that I needed. I also ran out of granulated sugar so I used a scant half a cup of that and the rest baking Stevia. It is definitely tart (hello delicious fresh lemon juice!) but I just added a lot of ice to my glass and it was perfect. Refreshing on a hot summer day- and I may just add some homemade watermelon vodka to it for a fun cocktail. Would definitely recommend- you can tweak to the flavor that you like pretty easily. Thanks for the recipe!

This truly is the best Lemonade ever. Made exactly as written as it was my first time.. So didn't want to mess around. This is a great treat.. And it reminds me of the Lemonade you can get at a Carnival. I don't drink much for anything sweet.. But found this really refreshing. Ended up using 8 lemons total, squeezed by hand. I did not find this to sweet at all. I added ice cubes to the simple syrup to cool down, put everything in a pitcher added ice and water to fill, did not measure water. To get more juice I microwaved the lemons 40 seconds for 3 at a time then I squeezed by putting the lemon inside of a long tong.

text:
Very good! I have made this twice and both times it has been a very natural and refreshing drink. My daughter has asked me to make it again tonight. I think instead of waiting for water to boil, I will use the microwave like "MYGIRLIESMOM"did. Hey, we are in the 21st Century now! To heat something up even a simple cup of water, we do not have to wait for the water to boil just stick a microwavable cup of water in the microwave to heat it up to boiling. Also, my last batch I tried to make strictly with Stevia and it did not taste as good as the first time when I made it exactly as the recipe. So, the amount of sugar mentioned in the recipe is what I will add. I think what I will do is if it is still not as sweet to my taste then I will add the Stevia. Cheers!!

This is a simple and excellent recipe.  I used fresh Lisbon lemons (like a Eureka lemon) from our tree so they are quite tart.  This recipe  gave a nice balance between the sour and sweet. I will do this one again because the grandkids are always asking for it.

userID:
14819049
Display Name:
Gorobei
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
3
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you look at a cross-section of the reviews of this lemonade recipe, you will see that some people find it too sweet, some find it too tart, but in any case, this is a good recipe to start with.  If it's too sweet, simply reduce the sugar and/or add more lemon juice, water, or ice.  If it's too tart, simply reduce the amount of lemon juice and/or add more sugar, water or ice.  If you follow the directions exactly, it comes out pretty well in any case. I like to drink it chilled but without ice, but I think the recipe will stand up to serving it over ice.  Try garnishing with lemon slices in the pitcher and/or in individual glasses.

I did a few modifications in my most recent attempt at making this, and you might want to try some as well.  I reduced the sugar to one and a half cups and used turbinado sugar.  I did not heat the sugar and water to make syrup first, I simply  added the sugar crystals directly to cool, filtered water in a sealable container, shook it up really well, then added the lemon juice and shook it up again.  The heating of the sugar in the water does not really do anything except facilitate the sugar crystals' going up into solution. Shaking the mixture vigorously does the same thing.  I also only used 7 cups of water, and although I have a citrus juicer, I experimented with store-bought lemon juice in a bottle.  I tasted the lemonade straight, and it was fine.  Over ice it would still be strong enough.  It's a fine recipe to play with, so have fun!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-11-29T15:45:16.29

Perfect proportions! I used 6 good sized lemons and got exactly 1.5 cups of lemon juice! I also took the advice of a previous reviewer and microwaved the water/sugar to make the simple syrup, then put a couple handfuls of ice cubes in to cool it down.  With the help of my food processor juicer attachment (and my 3 year old), the whole process took us about a half hour to make it.  We strained out the pulp because we are not "pulp people," but this recipe is delicious! I may even puree some fresh summer strawberries and make some strawberry lemonade!

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used two cups of lemon juice, 1-1/2 cups sugar and a 1/2 of water.  I boiled about half the water and added the sugar.  When it was dissolved I added it to everything else in a gallon pitcher filled with ice and the ice melts to make a gallon and cools it down.  It was delicious.  It's worth spending $20 on a quick juicer.  It took me about 3 minutes to get the juice for 2 cups.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one fine lemonade to usher in the beginning of summer.  The ratios of sugar, to water, to lemon are perfect and illicit just the right amount of pucker to your lips.  As another had suggested, the use of a microwave and ice cubes can hurry you on to Lemonirvana, 

Nuke 1 cup of water for 1 minute.  Add sugar to irradiated water.  Swirl into a syrupy translucent mixture.  Pour remaining water, ice, and lemon juice to jug.  Stir in syrup.  Jug-a-lug.  A note on the mysteries of ice: place ice into your measuring cup before adding the water to ensure an accurate measurement.

text:
Awesome! Great base recipe.  I used pure lemon juice from a bottle to make it easier.  I cut the sugar to 1 cup. I used ice and water for the remaining 7 cups of water u add at the end to cool it faster.  I threw 1/2 the mix in my blendtec and added a cup of frozen strawberries. Yum! We made these into popsicles and added a dash of heavy whipping cream to the pops too. With the remaining simple syrup and ice/water we added lime juice and frozen strawberries to make strawberry limeade.  Awesome if you like margaritas!

Delicious! Just made today. I hand squeezed 8 lemons and had about1 1/4 cup of juice. I used 1 1/4 cups of sugar with the cup of water and stirred on the stove on medium heat until it just dissolved. Added a little over 3 quarts of water and it came out perfect just like my Grandma makes! A little sweet but more tart.

text:
This was very good. I followed the recipe exactly the first time, and really liked it. However, it is more sweet than tart, and my family likes tart better, although that's just preference. So, I now make it using 1 1/4 or 1 1/2 cup sugar. Sometimes I use a little less water, to make it a little stronger. But the recipe is great as is, and it's very easy to tweak to specific likes. Sometimes I sub 1/2 cup lime juice for the lemon juice, which is great. It's also amazing frozen and turned into a slushy.

text:
This is a good Lemonade recipe.  I followed the directions the first time I made it, but found it way too sweet and after adding ice cubes to the glass, found the taste diluted too much.      The second time I made it I cut back on the sugar by a 1/2 cup and added only 5 cups of water (including the sugar water).  I then added ice cubes to the glasses and found it was much better tasting.

text:
I used 1 1/4 cup sugar because I like it my lemonade just a little sweet but not too much.  I had 8 largish lemons which gave me about 1 1/4 cup lemon juice.   I added a little from a bottle to make up the difference.  I also added 9 large strawberries (pureed) as well as the pulp from three of the lemons.  It ended up having the right mix of sweet and sour.  It was really nice to have a guideline to follow.  Thanks Jo!

amazing recipe for lemonade!
i squeezed the lemons by hand which really did not take too long...you dont really need to let the sugar+water mixture cool down..just add in the rest of the cold water...after i was done adding the water i put in a whole tray of ice cubes and mixed the lemonade really well in the blender...it took hardly 20 minutes to do it all..and result was AWESOMe..
most refreshing lemonade ever!

I liked it too.  I did not have time to wait for the hot syrup to cool so I heated up only 2 cups of water and added the sugar.  Heated it until the sugar dissolved, didn't quite come to a boil.  Then I poured it in the pitcher and added cold water to fill it about 3/4 way and filled the rest up with ice cubes.  Put it in the fridge and it was nice and cold in an hour.

text:
I tinkered a bit and found equal amounts of sugar and lemon juice (1 1/2 cups of each) are the best combination for me.  Other than that, this lemonade can't go wrong, no matter what kind of lemons you use.  The concentrate freezes well too, so you can make batches of it when lemons are cheap and enjoy your lemonade all year round.

text:
Excellent! Quick and refreshing. Dissolving the sugar in boiling water first was a great idea, but I took the advice of one of the other reviewers and used the hot syrup right away - adding ice cubes and additional water to chill the syrup.
